headline: The Catilinarian Conspiracy
description: A historical inquiry into the Catilinarian Conspiracy that becomes a meditation on authorship, truth, and the limits of historical knowledge. This post questions how we judge a man known only through his enemy’s voice.
whyItMatters: Because it exposes the fissure in historical certainty. When the only record is from the victors, what room remains for the vanished voice? This piece honors the historian's true task: not proof, but doubt.
articleExcerpt: That was the thing in all my reading — there is nary a scrap of Catiline’s voice left. Only echoes from his enemies.
sourceFragments: Cicero was a schemer, a plotter and fond of power, but he also deeply cared about the republic.
If all this is true, why does it feel incomplete?
What does it mean for the historical record to have its principal actor only known through the words of those who cast him as villain?
